titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the K. Leroy Irvis Papers, 1946-1995 AIS.1971.06
titlestmt.author: Archives Service Center Staff.

did.abstract: The K. Leroy Irvis Papers document the life of one of Pennsylvania's prominent politicians. Irvis, a Democrat, represented Pittsburgh in the Pennsylvania House of Representatives from 1958-1988. Among his achievements, Irvis was elected Speaker of the House in 1977, the first African-American to hold that position in any state legislature in the United States since Reconstruction. The collection contains a wide variety of material, including correspondence, legislative material, interviews, photographs, publications, and campaign literature.

bioghist.head: Biography
bioghist.p: Kirkland Leroy Irvis was born in Saugerties, N.Y., December 27, 1919, son of Francis H. and Harriet Ten Broeck (Cantine) Irvis. His education includes an A.B. summa cum laude in 1938 and an M.A. in 1939 from N.Y. State Teacher's College (now SUNY) in Albany. Irvis received an LL.B. in 1954 and a J.D. in 1969 from University of Pittsburgh Law School. Irvis received the title of Doctor of Laws from both Lincoln University and The State University of New York at Albany. He also received the Owens Fellowship in Law, The Order of the Coif, and was inducted into Phi Beta Kappa.

Prior to his successful political career, Irvis worked as a teacher, Pittsburgh steel worker, editor, civil rights worker, news commentator, law clerk, assistant district attorney, civilian attach√© to the War Department, and author. Irvis was a member of the Urban League of Pittsburgh, a life member of NAACP, served on the Board of Trustees of the University of Pittsburgh, and served on the Advisory Board of the University of Pittsburgh Medical School.

After his 1957 appointment as Assistant District Attorney in Pittsburgh, Irvis began his state political career. In 1958, he was elected to the Pennsylvania House of Representatives from Pittsburgh's Hill District. During this same year, his first wife, Katharyne Jones, passed away. Irvis became the Democratic Caucus Chairman in his third term in Congress, and he continued to rise through the ranks of leadership as Majority Caucus Chairman, Minority Whip, and Majority Leader. Along the way, he married Cathryn L. Edwards in 1973. In May 1977 the House unanimously elected him Speaker - the only African-American to hold the position in the United States at that time. In January 1979 the Democratic Caucus elected Irvis to serve as the Democratic Leader for the 1979-1980 session. He was re-elected to the same post for the 1981-82 session. He served again as speaker from 1983 until his retirement in 1988.

Irvis was a delegate to the 1967-1968 Pennsylvania Constitutional Convention and a delegate to the Democratic National Conventions in 1968, 1972, 1976, 1980, and 1984. During the 1980 Democratic National Convention, he served as Vice Chairman of the Pennsylvania Delegation and as Convention Co-Chairman. In 1982 Irvis was elected to serve as a member of the Democratic National Committee.

Irvis sponsored thousands of pieces of legislation addressing his concerns for education, civil rights, health, consumer protection, prison reform, housing, and governmental reform. His most noted achievements include the sponsorship and passage of legislation creating the Pennsylvania Human Relations Commission, Pennsylvania Higher Education Equal Opportunity Program, Pennsylvania Higher Education Assistance Agency, Minority Business Development Authority, House Ethics Committee, Lobbyist Registration Act, Legislative Audit Advisory Commission, House Bipartisan Management Committee, and the Pennsylvania Council on the Arts. Irvis is also credited with suggesting the creation of the Community College System in the Commonwealth. Other noteworthy education legislation Irvis sponsored included the 1966 bill that made the University of Pittsburgh, Penn State, Lincoln, and Temple state-related universities.

Among the organizations to have formally honored Irvis are the NAACP, University of Pennsylvania, Lincoln University of Pennsylvania, and Dominion Resources. The University of Pittsburgh has a K. Leroy Irvis Reading Room in Hillman Library. In 2003, the South Office Building within the Pennsylvania Capitol Complex was renamed the Speaker K. Leroy Irvis Office Building. Pennsylvania Democratic Party Chairman T. J. Rooney described Rep. Irvis as, "one of greatest legislative giants that the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania has ever seen ... [and] one of the most admired and respected Pennsylvanians we'll ever know."

Away from politics, Irvis was an accomplished artist and author. In the same year he retired (1988), Irvis wrote a book of poems called, This Land of Fire, published by Temple University. His wood sculptures have been displayed in exhibits throughout the country. Irvis died at age 86 of cancer.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The K. Leroy Irvis Papers document the life of one of Pennsylvania's most prominent politicians. The collection contains a wide variety of material including correspondence, legislative material, interviews, campaign literature, publications, photographs, awards, audiovisual media, and newspaper clippings. The collection documents Irvis's early career and education, his campaigns and his career as a Representative in the Pennsylvania State House of Representatives, his time as Speaker of the Pennsylvania State House, his legislative priorities and accomplishments, his personal life and hobbies, and the accolades and honors he earned during his career as a public servant. Areas of concentration in the collection include: the Pennsylvania Legislature, higher education, prison reform, housing, Pennsylvania history, senior citizens, National Democratic Conventions, Pennsylvania African-American culture and history, mental health, civil rights, and Irvis' relationship with his family and constituents.
Note: Folders 61, 62, 67, 77, 104, 105, 106, 151, and 152 from the 1974 Addition and folder 26 from the 1995 Addition have been removed from this collection.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection has been arranged into the following series:

Throughout the collection, subseries are frequently divided by the date materials in the series were acqiured by the University of Pittburgh rather than by content. Therefore, similar or related materials may have been donated at different times and included in different subseries under the same series heading.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Folder 171 of 1971 Deposit is closed and has been removed from the collection.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: The collection, a gift from K. Leroy Irvis, consists of an original deposit in 1971.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: K. Leroy Irvis Papers, 1947-1995, AIS.1971.06, Archives & Special Collections, University of Pittsburgh Library System

odd.head: Previous Citation
odd.p: K. Leroy Irvis Papers, 1947-1995, AIS.1971.06, Archives Service Center, University of Pittsburgh
K. Leroy Irvis Papers, 1947-1995, ais 76:1, Archives Service Center, University of Pittsburgh

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This collection was processed by Archives Service Center staff in 1971, 1974, 1975, 1979, 1980, 1995, 2010, and 2017. Two graduate students, Shelley Byron and Ashley Taylor, were instrumental in processing the 2010 addition. As noted above, the collection was processed on seven different occasions because it was donated to the Archives Service Center in several additions during the span of K. Leroy Irvis' political career. Since Irvis was such an important political figure in Pennsylvania, the ASC deemed it necessary and important to make the collection available to the public as each addition was donated. The collection was thematically organized in 2017 to connect similar material from each addition.

userestrict.head: Copyright
userestrict.p: Permission for publication is given on behalf of the University of Pittsburgh as the owner of the physical items and is not intended to include or imply permission of the copyright holder, which must also be obtained.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series contains biographical information written by or about Irvis, including correspondence with biographers and a sketch of his family background. In addition, there are awards and a career profile, as well as information on Irvis's leisure activities with model airplanes and wood carving.

More information on Irvis's personal life may be found in Series III: Personal; further information on his hobbies and other aspects of his personal life may be found in Series III: Personal, Series XII: Katharyne Irvis, Series XIII: Cathryn Irvis, and Series XIV: Photographs.
The series is arranged into two subseries based on the date the materials were acquired by the University of Pittsburgh.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Subseries 1 contains correspondence, news releases, awards, and information Irvis's family, hobbies and professional memberships. These materials are arranged by subject.

did.unittitle: Sanford R. Starobin Biography: News Release
Family background, brief sketches, notes, etc.
Correspondence of Mark Schwartz relating to KLI biography

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains a profile of Irvis written for an unknown publication in the early 1970s.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series contains information about Irvis's legal career. Irvis was awarded a degree in law from the University of Pittsburgh School of Law in 1954. He was employed by the legal firm, Rose Schmidt and Dixon, where he oversaw a number of legal cases and eventually became Pittsburgh's Assistant District Attorney in 1957. This series includes records evidencing Irvis' law degree including his membership to the Allegheny County Bar Association, the American Bar Association, as well as his Attorney Certification. In addition to his certifications, the series contains analyses, appointments, cases, correspondence and publications. Most materials date from the 1970s and 80s, when Irvis was serving in the Pennsylvania State House of Representatives.
More information on Irvis's legal career can be found in Series VII, Subseries 2: Irvis's Early Employment.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series contains correspondence, memos, photographs and other documentation of Irvis's personal life and leisure time. Of particular note are the subseries and folders that document on his creative writing and poetry, as well as the documentation of his hobbies, including his woodcarving and model airplane building. In addition, there is some documentation of his schooling, including his time at Albany Senior High and his higher education, including articles and his M.A. thesis. There is also some documentation of Irvis's travel, including trips to Cote d'Ivoire and the Central African Republic, as well as his research and preparation for those trips and his planned Pan-African business ventures. Finally, there is some documentation of Irvis's awards and honors later in life, including his obituary, tributes, and some awards.

This series is divided into ten subseries, divided both by subject and by the date the material was acquired by the University of Pittsburgh. There is additional personal correspondence in Series VI, Subseries iv: Correspondence (2010 addition). There is also addional material pertaining to Irvis's personal life in Series I: Biography, Series XII: Katharyne Irvis, and Series XIII: Cathryn Irvis. Some of Irvis's original sculptures and artwork may be found in this collection in Subseries XVII: Awards, Realia, Etc. Photographs of Irvis's work may be found in Series XIV: Photographs.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This subseries primarily contains correspondence from family and other personal matters such as contributions, subscriptions, invitations, memorabilia, and miscellaneous social and financial files. This series is arranged by subject.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains information about yearly expenses related to Irvis's office in the Pennsylvania State House of Representatives. There also is scant documentation of expenses of some House committees on which Irvis served.

did.unittitle: Personal and Travel Subject Files (1979 Addition)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains Irvis's personal subject files, which contain newsclippings and programs that document his interest in theatre, history, and religion, among other topics. Irvis's interest in travel, including travel brochures and articles clipped from periodicals and magazines, is also well-represented. The subseries consists largely of correspondence, periodicals, news clippings, articles, and publications.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This subseries documents Irvis's personal interest, including his work as an avid artist, woodcarver, model airplane builder, and writer. The series consists of publications, notes, poetry, artwork, information on model airplanes and correspondence, 1946-1947. These files are arranged by subject.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This subseries largely consists of Irvis's incoming personal correspondence, including letters, holiday and birthday greeting cards, and other personal correspondence. The materials are arranged chronologically by subject.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains materials relating to Irvis' hobbies, including model airplanes, brass and woodwind bands, craftsman guilds, art and artists, and wood sculpting. These materials include correspondence, brochures, clippings, awards, and publications. Of particular note is the folder which contains brochures, programs, and awards for shows of Irvis' wood sculptures.
Some of Irvis's original sculptures and artwork may be found in this collection in Subseries XVII: Awards, Realia, Etc. Photographs of Irvis's work may be found in Series XIV: Photographs.

did.unittitle: ArtSourceBook: A Directory of Minority Artists in Pa.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This subseries documents Irvis's work as a writer; Irvis wrote academic research, fiction, essays, and poetry throughout his life. The subseries includes correspondence with publishers, manuscripts, publications, clippings, and notebooks containing fiction, poetry, notes, observations, and Irvis's M.A. thesis. The majority of these writing are from Irvis' youth and college years. These materials are arranged by subject.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The material in this subseries relates to Irvis's personal interests including model airplane and RC aeronautics clubs, art, sculpture and woodcarving. It contains notes and sketches completed by Irvis throughout his lifetime, childhood mementos, and membership cards for the many organizations to which he belonged. This subseries is arranged alphabetically by subject.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Irvis took great interest in poetry and composed a large amount of it. Some of his compilations of poetry include This Land of Fire and Lions and Great Bronze Bars. There are various editions of each of these within this subseries, as well as manuscript editions. In addition to full compilations of poetry, this subseries also contains loose poems completed by Irvis with some accompanying handwritten notes. This subseries is arranged alphabetically by subject.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Irvis took several trips to African countries, including the Central African Republic, and the Cote d'Ivoire. This subseries documents these trips, as well as Irvis's research on the conditions and history of these areas and information Irvis gathered about investing in Africa as part of a Pan-African business venture. The subseries is arranged alphabetically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series contains information on legislation that Irvis supported or introduced during his career in the Pennsylvania House of Representatives. It contains Irvis's statements, speeches and remarks about many legislative issues, as well as memoranda, correspondence, notes, and reports pertaining to legislation. In addition, the series documents Irvis's committee and leadership work in the Pennsylvania House of Representatives through items such as House calendars, documentation of legislative commissions, information on standing committees and membership lists.

The series is divided into three subseries based on the date the material was acquired by the University of Pittsburgh: the first from the original 1971 deposit, the second from the 1980 addition, and the third from the 2010 addition.
Supporting materials, including contemporaneous newsclippings, may be found in Series XVI: Media and in the scrapbooks in Series XVII, Subseries 3: Realia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains legislation introduced in the Pennsylvania House of Representatives including health, welfare, education, and government resolutions. House calendars and statements, speeches, and remarks by Irvis along with House offices held by Irvis and Committees and Commissions on which he served are included in this series. Series II is arranged alphabetically, by subject, except for the House calendars (Boxes 4-5) which are arranged by date. The House calendars are personal copies of bills introduced with holograph notes written by Irvis.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This subseries includes the text of bills and resolutions on which Irvis worked and voted during his time in the Pennsylvania House of Representatives between 1963 and 1987, as well as correspondence relating to those pieces of legislation. This series is arranged chronologically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The material in this subseries pertains to Irvis' career as a member of the Pennsylvania House of Representatives (1959-1988). During the span of his legislative career, he assisted with the introduction of a massive amount of legislation into the Pennsylvania House of Representatives. Some of this legislation is documented in this subseries in the form of a finalized House or Senate Bills and resolutions. Along the lines of legislation, Irvis collected information on Pennsylvania specific issues including Home Rule and the potential increase of the personal property tax; as well as how both issues adversely affected constituents.

The subseries also contains materials Irvis accumulated during his routine work day. These materials include House memorandums, yearly calendars, and staff communications. In relation to his legislative career, Irvis went on several trips which are documented in this subseries. This subseries is arranged alphabetically by subject.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series contains subject files maintained by Irvis during his tenure as a legislator. The subject files represent a wide range of issues that affected Irvis's work in the Pennsylvania State House of Representatives and which affected his constituents in Pittsburgh. While the subjects are varied, many relate to Irvis's long-standing legislative priorities and social concerns. There are many files that relate to educational issues, including both K-12 and higher education, the concerns of the African-American community and civil rights, as well as community development. Related material on legislation Irvis considered and enacted exists in Series IV: Legislative Files; there is also related material in Series VII: Community.
The series is arranged in four subseries based on the date the material was acquired by the University of Pittsburgh.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of subject files on agencies, social issues, and other work-related topics kept by Irvis between 1947 and 1971. All items refer to Pennsylvania unless otherwise specified. Some of the notable subjects include discrimination, Pennsylvania Human Relations Commission, Coal Mining, Education (K-12/Pittsburgh Public Schools, higher education, educational institutions), Health and Welfare, Insurance, Labor, and Mental Health Investigations. It is arranged alphabetically.

They include files on education, legislature, prison reform, and speaking engagements. The files are arranged alphabetically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series consists primarily of Irvis's professional correspondence with constituents, legislators and other government officials, staffers, and community organizers during his legislative career. Also included are related items, such as job applications sent to Irvis's office and formal invitations. Finally, there is a substantial amount of correspondence about the University of Pittsburgh contained in Subseries iv of this series.

This series has been arranged into four subseries by the date the material was acquired by the University of Pittsburgh. Subseries 3 and 4 of this series also contain a substantial amount of personal correspondence; other personal correspondence, some with fellow legislators, can be found in Series II: Personal. Additional community-related and election-related correspondence can be found in Series VII: Community and Series VIII: Campaigns, respectively.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This subseries consists primarily of correspondence from constituents but also includes correspondence about professional licensure and correspondence regarding miscellaneous conferences. The records are arranged by subject.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains Irvis's professoinal correspondence, including job applications, correspondence about scholarships, invitations, crank letters, as well as a folder of memos. General correspondence is arranged alphabetically, but some is arranged by subject.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains correspondence to and from state officials, as well as communication from constituents and personal letters. Materials are arranged chronologically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The correspondence in this subseries is mainly incoming communication to Irvis from state officials, constituents, staff, or personal family and friends. The subseries also contains a large collection of personal greeting cards to the Irvis', some of which have been received from state officials. The correspondence subseries has been arranged according to its personal, community involvement, legislative, or University of Pittsburgh oriented nature. The subject matter of some correspondence overlaps between two of the aforementioned topics, so a majority of the correspondence has been identified as personal in nature. This subseries is arranged chronologically by date.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Irvis was active in community organizations and programs, particularly ones related to arts and culture, racial justice and equality, housing, and education. This series documents his involvement with many of those organizations through correspondence, publications, programs and pamphlets created by the organizations, reports, press releases, and newsclippings. It also documents some of Irvis's early employment in community-related enterprises, such as his time at the Urban League, with the Pittsburgh Courier, and as a law clerk and practicing lawyer.
This series has been divided into subseries based on both the date the material was acquired by the University of Pittsburgh as well as by subject.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains memos, correspondence, brochures, reports, and press releases related to community events in the Pittsburgh area, 1970-1978. This series is arranged chronologically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains clippings, programs, correspondence, and other materials related to Irvis' employment, 1945-1955. These file are arranged by subject.

scopecontent.p: This subseries contains clippings, programs brochures, correspondence, press releases, reports, and statements relating to various, cultural, civic, and educational organizations that Irvis has been associated. This series is arranged alphabetically by organization.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of materials related to the Camp Hill Prison Riots of October 1989. Inmates held the State Correctional Institute at Camp Hill for four days. There were no escapes, however, 138 corrections officers were injured and 17 more were held hostage. Seventy inmates were also injured and 14 buildings were destroyed. The resulting costs for police, rescue, repairs and cleanup ran into the millions and were paid by Pennsylvania taxpayers. Irvis was a member of the Governor's Commission to investigate the riots.

did.unittitle: Governor's Commission on Riots- Final Report
Photographs of Camp Hill Prison (after the riot)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Irvis' interest in African American affairs began early upon his arrival in Pittsburgh in the 1940s. During this time, Irvis joined the Urban League of Pittsburgh and took part in demonstrations against discrimination in Pittsburgh department stores. The African American Interests subseries documents Irvis' involvement with organizations and the African American community. Irvis was involved with a number of organizations including the Afro-American Historical and Cultural Museum, the American Foundation for Negro Affairs, the Black Elected Officials Summit, the NAACP, the National Black Caucus of State Legislatures, the Pennsylvania Black Conference on Higher Education, the Pennsylvania Legislative Black Caucus, and the University of Pittsburgh as each corresponded to issues pertinent to the African American Community. Irvis' membership within these organizations has produced event and conference information, pamphlets, organization literature, news clippings, publications and flyers. The subseries is arranged alphabetically by subject.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Irvis was interested in providing housing opportunities for all people, regardless of financial ability. The material in this subseries contains research compiled by Irvis concerning housing issues in Pittsburgh and Pennsylvania, articles he authored concerned with the availability of equal-opportunity housing, and legislative material related to the various issues he identified. This subseries is arranged alphabetically by subject.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series documents Irvis's own campaigns for the Pennsylvania State House of Representatives as well as his involvement in some of the campaigns of his colleagues in the State House and Senate. The series consists primarily of promotional material (flyers, posters, buttons, fact sheets, etc.) and correspondence, as well as a substantial amount of financial documentation, including donations and expenses.
The series has been divided into four subseries based on the date the material was acquired by the University of Pittsburgh.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This subseries includes posters, flyers, correspondence, clippings, notes and literature from Irvis' election campaign, 1958.

did.unittitle: Irvis' Campaigns / Committee to Re-elect Irvis, (1995 Addition)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This subseries includes correspondence, expense reports, contributions, and other re-election materials relating to campaigns, 1978-1986. These materials are arranged by chronologically by campaign.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This subseries includes correspondence, brochures, and other campaign materials for colleagues of Irvis, 1976-1994. Included are materials for John, Cohn, Dwight Evans, and Jimmy Carter. These materials are arranged by alphabetically by subject.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The campaign subseries includes posters, flyers, clippings, literature, and financial information from Irvis' election campaigns. The subseries is arranged chronologically by election year.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series contains documentation of Irvis's involvement in educational activities during and after his time as a legislator. He was invited to speak and attend functions at many higher education institutions because of his legislative work in that area; many of those invitations, programs, correspondence, and other documentation are represented here. There is also some documentation of Irvis's legislative work relating to education, including the ACT 101 legislation and the establishment of the Pennsylvania Higher Education Assistance Committee, and files on other educational programs and legislation. In addition, Irvis served on the Board of Trustees for the University of Pittsburgh and assisted in planning and fundraising for the Bidwell Training Center and Pittsburgh Voyager projects. The series consists largely of reports, invitations, programs, and correspondence.

The series is arranged into five subseries, both by subject and by the date the materials were acquired by the University of Pittsburgh. There is additional information in Irvis's educational legislative work in Series IV: Legislative Files and Series XI: Speeches and Interviews. Many of the subjects represented here are also represented in Series V: Subject Files.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This subseries includes commencement invitations, programs, correspondence, memos, and speaking engagements at various schools and universities. Pennsylvania colleges and universities such as Penn State, University of Pittsburgh, Temple, and Dickinson are included. This subseries is arranged alphabetically by institution.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Irvis served on the Board of Trustees at the University of Pittsburgh for a number of years and collected a large amount of university-related documentation. A majority of the material in this subseries relates to Irvis' position on the Board of Trustees and includes agendas, memorandums, correspondence, and event information. In addition, this subseries also includes information on Irvis' involvement in the development of African American programs at the University of Pittsburgh, as well as the African American Heritage Classroom. This subseries is arranged alphabetically by subject.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The Bidwell Cultural and Training Center was established in 1968 by the Bidwell Street Presbyterian Church and the Manchester Community as a response to the riots of the 1960s and lack of jobs for minorities. By 1972, the Bidwell Cultural and Training Center hired William Strickland, Jr. to lead the Center. Strickland urged the creation of a "unique learning environment serving the needs of the community and providing educational opportunities to anyone who aspired to positively change their lives." By the 1980s, the Center formally changed its name to the Bidwell Training Center and came to operate as it does today, providing education in the high tech and medical industries as well as the horticulture industry. Irvis took great interest in the original creation of the BTC and acted as an investor. In turn, he was placed on the Board. As a Board member, Irvis collected various agendas, correspondence, memorandums, and event information. This subseries is arranged alphabetically by subject.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Irvis took a great interest in education during his legislative career, having pursued a profession as a teacher before entering politics. He was responsible for passing educational reforms during his term in the Pennsylvania House, notably the creation of the state's community college system and the Pennsylvania Higher Education Assistance Agency, which helped encourage and enable more students to pursue degrees beyond their high school diplomas. The material in this subseries includes information relating to this legislation, as well as research about educational issues. This subseries is arranged alphabetically by subject.

did.unittitle: Academic Assistance Programs Conference, Penn State
Andrew M. Bradley Scholarship Awards Banquet
Education for International Competence in Pennsylvania
Pennsylvania Association of Colleges and Universities
Scholarships, Fellowships, and Loans News Service

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The Pittsburgh Voyager was a project founded in 1991 by a group of parents who desired to use the rivers of Pittsburgh as a teaching tool, an "experimental classroom to get children excited about science, mathematics, and learning." Irvis was involved in the development of the project, which led to his collection of correspondence, meeting minutes, and foundation materials. The physical vessel is currently operating as the Riverquest, which began in 2006, where it continues the educational mission of the original Pittsburgh Voyager. This subseries is arranged alphabetically by subject.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series contains information about Irvis's political work on behalf of the Democratic party and other political organizations, as well as some information about lawsuits and other non-legislative work during his time as a Pennsylvania State Representative. Of particular note are the mateials in Subseries 2, 4, and 5 on Irvis's involvement in the Democratic National Convention. Irvis was vice-chair of the Pennsylvania Delegation to the DNC in 1976 and 1980 and was on the credentials comittee in 1988.
The series is divided into five subseries, organized both by subject and by the date the material was acquired by the University of Pittsburgh.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains correspondence, enclosures, newsclippings, and campaign materials for various political campaigns. All folders pertain to other politicians except for folder 95 which contains materials from Irvis' County Court Judge campaign and withdrawal, 1965. This subseries is arranged alphabetically by subject.

did.unittitle: Campaigns- County Court Judge campaign and withdrawal

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains convention packets, periodicals, materials, and brochures from Democratic National Conventions attended by Irvis. The materials are arranged chronologically.

did.unittitle: House of Representatives, Law Suits, etc. (1995 Addition)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This subseries includes correspondence, briefs, press releases, and newsclippings from legislation, law suits, and individual cases in which Irvis was involved. Some of the subjects and cases contained in this series include the electoral college, minority studies, Pennsylvania Economy League, Pennsylvania House of Representatives, and the Three Rivers Improvement Project. This series is arranged alphabetically by subject. Of particular note in this series is a scroll presented to Irvis on behalf of the Afro-American Historical and Cultural Museum.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains convention packets from Democratic National Conventions, 1968-1988, and correspondence, newsletters, and publications from political organizations including the Pennsylvania Legislative Black Caucus and Pennsylvania Democratic Committee. This subseries is arranged chronologically by subject.

did.unittitle: Democratic National Convention- Souvenirs, Maps, etc.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: As a Democratic member of the Pennsylvania House of Representatives, Irvis found himself highly involved with the Democratic Party. His involvement garnished correspondence, newsletters, and publications from the party as well as the Democratic National Committee. Since Irvis was highly involved with the DNC, he often served as a delegate at the Democratic National Convention. The materials which pertain to the national conventions are packets, periodicals, brochures, and convention memorabilia. This subseries is arranged alphabetically by subject.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series consists largely of interviews with Irvis in his last few years as a legislator before his retirement in 1988; these interviews cover all aspects of Irvis's life, including his childhood and family, his education, and his career as a lawyer and a legislator. In addition, there are some transcripts or texts from Irvis's speeches for community and civic organizations, as well as some invitations from groups inviting Irvis to speak and Irvis's correspondence about speaking engagements.
This series is arranged into three subseries according to the date the material was acquired by the University of Pittsburgh.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This subseries includes speeches, addresses, lectures, and interviews given by Irvis, 1969-1970. These include a speech to the Catholic Diocese of Harrisburg, address to Franklin and Marshall College, and a transcript of a TV interview which was hosted by Warren Dean and a panel of three Pennsylvania journalists, 1970. This series is arranged by subject.

did.unittitle: Address, Franklin and Marshall College, (Tape and Transcription)
Urban Politics Lecture, "Black Man in Politics", (Tape Only)
Broadcast interview, "Black Perspective on the News", (Tape and Transcript)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains transcripts from taped interviews. Folders 159-162 consist of transcripts of Irvis answering questions that had been sent to him in 1981. Folders 163-177 contain interviews conducted by Janet Patterson, 1986-1987 and include all aspects of Irvis' life including childhood, campaigning, and presidents. These materials are arranged by date of interview.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This subseries includes invitations, correspondence, pamphlets, honors, programs, and publications regarding Irvis' business and speaking engagements, 1980-1991. This subseries is arranged alphabetically by subject.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series contains materials related to K. Leroy Irvis' first wife, Katharyne (1918-1959). After attending the Tuskegee Institute, Katharyne received a Bachelor of Science from Prairie View College. Kathryne was involved with a wide array of organizations including her career at the Pittsburgh Courier, membership at the Urban League of Pittsburgh, NAACP, National Council of Negro Women, and Democrats for United Action. She was also a skilled tennis player who played competitively and won many titles.
This series is arranged into two subseries based on the date that the materials were acquired by the University of Pittsburgh.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This subseries documents the many awards and titles Katharyne Irvis won as a tennis player including the National Negro Women's Championship (Doubles - 1942; Singles - 1945), and the American Tennis Association National Women's Singles Title, 1946. She was an advertising rep for the Pittsburgh Courier as well as a member of the Urban League of Pittsburgh, NAACP, National Council of Negro Women, and Democrats for United Action. These records are arranged by subject and include newsclippings, manuscripts, and other materials.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This subseries includes records relating heavily to Katharyne Irvis' earlier life and education, as well as correspondence from K. Leroy Irvis from the duration of time while they lived at a distance from one another. This subseries is arranged alphabetically by subject.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Cathryn, Irvis' second wife, was involved in several organizations including the Women in Urban Crisis, the Million Woman March, the Community College of Allegheny County, the Port Authority of Allegheny County, the Black Women's Political Crusade, the March of Dimes, and the National Association of Negro Business and Professional Women's Club, Inc. In addition to the organizations she was involved in, Mrs. Irvis was also highly involved in the organization of the International Year of the Child. She was a board member of Community College of Allegheny County (CCAC), Port Authority of Allegheny County (PAT), and Redevelopment Authority of Allegheny County, among other organizations. These materials also include information on the Black Women's Political Crusade, Pennsylvania Council for the Arts, and Vote America.
This series is divided into two subseries based on the date the materials in each were acquired by the University of Pittsburgh.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains correspondence, programs, speeches, awards, and materials regarding Irvis' second wife, Mrs. Cathryn Irvis.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The subseries focuses on Cathryn Irvis, highlights her organizational involvement and is arranged alphabetically by subject.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series contains photographs relating to Irvis's life and career, including his personal life, hobbies and artistic work, his legislative and legal work, and his speaking engagements, educational work, and civic involvement. Some photographs have associated newsclippings, notes, or other documentation.
The photoraphs are divided into three subseries based on the date the materials were originally acquired by the University of Pittsburgh.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains a number of images that correspond to subject titles of aforementioned subseries. Some of these subjects include African American interests, Cathryn Irvis, Community involvement, Democratic Party involvement, Legal Career, Legislative Career, and Personal. In addition to the subseries listed above, the Photographs subseries also contains images of Irvis at various events throughout his career. In this subseries, the photographs are arranged alphabetically by subject.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The media subseries contains audiovisual materials which relate to materials in several other series in the collection. These formats include VHS tapes, cassette tapes, magnetic tape, as well as DVDs. The audiovisual materials chronicle events from the following subseries: Community, Campaigns, Legislative, and Personal. Some of the audiovisual material captures Irvis directly, while other material relates to Irvis or his legislative and personal interests. The series has been divided into two subseries: audoi and video. Further, material is arranged alphabetically by related subseries, and then alphabetically by title.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains audio materials in various formats. Some items are recordings of Irvis speaking in professoinal situations or giving interviews, others are materials about Irvis or materials that Irvis collected relating to his work as a state representative, his legislative goals, or his hobbies and interests.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series contains newspaper clippings and news releases collected by Irvis over the course of his educational, legal, and legislative career. The subjects of the clippings are varied, but many relate to legislation that Irvis considered or sponsored during his time in the Pennsylvania State House of Representatives. Other clippings relate to civil rights and racial justice or other issues such as educational access and incarceration that Irvis championed throughout his career.

The series is arranged into four subseries based on the date the materials were acquired by the University of Pittsburgh. Related material may exist in Series IV: Legislative Files, Series V: Subject Files, or Series X: Political Activities.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains news clippings of various subjects from primarily Pennsylvania newspapers. This series is arranged alphabetically by subject and includes subjects such as legislature, taxes, transportation, and budget.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains one folder which includes news releases, primarily relating to taxation, for which there is not a separate subject file.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains newspaper clippings concerning politicians, legislation, passage of laws, and issues, 1946-1969. This series is arranged by Legislature and then by date.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains a clippings file (mostly Pennsylvania newspapers) arranged alphabetically by subject and a clippings file arranged by date. Some of the subjects include elections, liquor, poetry, taxes, and universities. The date files include 1949-1994.

did.unittitle: Negroes and the War by Chandler Owen

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The news clippings contained within this subseries have been collected by Irvis and his second wife, Cathryn. In addition to highlighting Irvis' life and achievements, the news clippings pertain to a wide variety of issues including legislation, community involvement, education, poetry, Cathryn Irvis, African American interests, and various other issues related to Pittsburgh and/or Irvis. This subseries is arranged chronologically by date.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series consists largely of plaques, statuettes, framed photographs, and other items given to Irvis as awards or honors over his long public service career. While the awards are from many different groups, most come from educational groups and organizations dedicated to social, racial, and economic justice. Educational awards include honorary doctorates from many Pennsylvania-area colleges as well as awards from student groups, University departments and programs, and educational advocacy organizations. Irvis also recieved many awards for his leadership on racial issues, including recognition by the NAACP (local and national), the Pennsylvania Black Conference on Higher Education and the National Black Conference of State Legislators. The series also contains some personal realia, most from Irvis's time as a Representative and Speaker of the Pennsylvania State House of Representatives, including gavels, paperweights, date books, and license plates.
The series has been divided into three subseries by the date the materials were acquired by the University of Pittsburgh.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains objects belonging to and collected by K. Leroy Irvis, including date books, paperweights, a gavel, certificates, bookmarks, awards, and cassette tapes.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Irvis was awarded or honored by several institutions throughout his lifetime. These awards and honorary degrees were bestowed upon him by a wide variety of academic institutions ranging from high schools to universities. Irvis was also honored by institutional organizations such as the NAACP, the Pennsylvania Black Conference on Higher Education, the Sickle Cell Society, the Supreme Court of Pennsylvania, and the Hill House Association, among various others. This subseries also contains each Pennsylvania House of Representatives Certificate Irvis received upon election to his legislative seat in the house. This subseries is described at an itemized level.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The material in the Realia subseries was mainly collected by Irvis over the duration of his life. Much of the memorabilia reflects activities or events that he participated in or was honored at. Some of these items include invitations, guest passes, plaques, and medallions. In addition, a large portion of the memorabilia is representative to Irvis' career as a member of the Pennsylvania House of Representatives. These items include, but are not limited to gavels, pins, license plates, and stamps. This subseries has been listed at an itemized level.
